Title: Facebook is fun and cool, but not always an environment that encourages growth.
Pro: the free food, really bright employees
Con: some of the employees feel a sense of entitlement that comes through in day-to-day interactions...very young upper level management..inexperience shows

Title: Most fun and rewarding job I've ever had.
Pro: smart people, challenging projects, refreshing to be with co-workers that love coming to work each day
Con: in a move fast culture, things are always changing and you have to roll with the punches

Title: Data entry
Pro: Communication, and support system from co-workers or higher ups. Very competitive and challenging when it comes to getting a lot of customers.
Con: A lot of work, and moving around if you don't like walking around too much. And sometimes you might not get a break for lunch.

Title: Great place to work!
Pro: Love the college campus-like feel, the open culture, and the high level of trust placed on all employees.
Con: As the company continues to grow, more layers of of hierarchy are being introduced (albeit unavoidable), and as a result, it's tougher to interact with the leadership

Title: Flat structure, very transparent (varies with teams)
Pro: Encourages uncommon ideas, move fast and break things
Con: Heard of a completely different environment from friends/ex employees on other teams.

Title: Software Engineer
Pro: reasonable work life balance, free meals, free gym membership
Con: Monoculture. Most employees are young fresh out of college grads. A lot of people move on to different tech companies within 2 -3 years. I'm not sure why there's so much turnover when compensation and perks are good.

Title: Engineering training specialist
Pro: Facebook really respects its employees and is very interested in diversity and that everyone is treated and compensated fairly. Zuck is a great leader
Con: The work life balance can be a challenge, but overall Facebook really does care about trying to make this better.

Title: Referral Program Specialist
Pro:
Flexible environment 
Tons of opportunity to learn and be exposed to a wide variety of roles 
Exposure to other ops roles 
Learn how to pull and manipulate data 
Great career move in either recruiting or ops
Con:
High volume 
Manual tracking

Title: Still a fantastic place to work
Pro:
- The people are very caring and smart 
- Great culture of management 
- Great perks 
- Good work life balance
Con:
- PR cycle 
- Commute to SF

Title: Great place to work
Pro: The benefits, perks, and opportunities for growth are among the best in the industry.
Con: A lot of pressure to perform. Oncall sometimes means being available outside of normal business hours.

Title: Fantastic place to work
Pro: Excellent benefits and a company that truly does care about the people who make the company run.
Con: Work/life balance can be tough at times, but that is to be expected at an industry leading tech company. And, the entitlement that employees often exhibit is disheartening.

Title: The best work of your life
Pro: You get to do some of the most rewarding work of your life at the scale of Facebook, with some of the best people and support systems. Fast paced with high expectations, an open culture and diverse workplace.
Con: None at this time AFAICT

Title: Best place to learn!
Pro: Amazing people, perks, and so much to learn. No matter what vertical when you join Facebook you learn so much from really smart folks all around you.
Con: Goals are challenging - so one has to manage work/life balance. But FB supports that quite a bit!

Title: Takes care of their employees
Pro: The company goes above and beyond to keep their employees happy. The working culture is great. The pay increases and promotions are fair and merit based. There is a good amount of potential for career growth.
Con: None I can think of yet.

Title: Amazing.
Pro: Great culture, people are thrilled to be there and that's infectious. The various perks don't hurt and you will constantly feel pushed to do your best.
Con: Busy environment- understaffed in some key areas so it can be occasionally difficult to move forward with any work.

Title: Experience of a lifetime
Pro: Lot of independence in choosing your projects, recognition for innovation, complex problems, daily code pushes to production, awesome peers.
Con: Constant inflow into upper management chain from other companies, so harder to move up the ladder if you're not on a crucial project.

Title: Work and learn from really smart people
Pro:
- Great people
- Free food
- Amazing culture that focuses on impact
- Lots of work
- As much responsibility as you want
Con:
- Lots of work
- Takes time to learn how to work at Facebook
- Your career is in your hands

Title: Fantastic place to work
Pro: Moves fast on projects, efficient processes for workflow, excellent tools in place to get work done, great people, amazing benefits, wonderful work/life balance
Con: Far from SF and commute time is really long

Title: Truly the best company to work for
Pro:
- flexibility to make your role your own
- open culture (truly open doesn't just say it is)
- appreciates their employees- perks and benefits are amazing
- company feels like family
- work life balance is appreciated and respected
Con: #NAME?

Title: Technical Recruiter
Pro:
+Impact
+Working on really cool stuff
+Ownership
+Culture
+Future of the company looks really positive and bright
+Making the world more open and connected
+You learn a lot from really awesome people around you
Con: -Recruiters aren't allowed to work remote.

Title: Relatively New Engineer Perspective
Pro: So many smart people that are super humble and easy to interact with. Facebook keeps titles and ranks hidden so company feels very flat. Perks are incredible they really care about their employees.
Con: Company has grown a lot feels maybe less tight knit than in old days.

Title: Facebook HQ
Pro:
* Really strong company leadership
* Excellent culture
* Encouraging diversity
Con:
* Very intense, leaving you with little time to reflect and be thoughtful 
* Fast growth leading to diluted culture

Title: Not a Diverse Company
Pro: Great employment brand and perks
Con: Was attracted to FB because of its Diversity message but it was a sad illusion. I'm HIspanic and women and since I joined the company they put me this HIspanic tag. Don't feel included by my peers and even by my manager, who is a global leader. Internally the company believes they include the people but never dare to deeply talk about the non inclusive culture we have here (Maning Bias training and tribes are only the top of this iceberg). Some Latinos friend already left the company and I might be the next.

Title: Needs to work on internal management
Pro: Amazing experience to be a part of a company which makes meaningful impact everyday
Con:
Some teams are becoming big and hence your impact may seem to dilute. 
Not very helpful in movement across orgs

Title: Best place to work... what a change from my previous employers
Pro: Mark Zuckerberg is phenomenal. Amazing leadership team. Very open, no BS, great mission. Great perks. Work and teammates are very enjoyable.
Con: I do not know yet.

Title: How it was
Pro: its fun to work with them because they sometimes are calm about there Facebook being hacked
Con: its hard to work with crazy people

Title: Software engineering intern
Pro: Great company values, a lot of thought going in everything being done at the company; open culture: visibility and accessibility to management
Con: always very ambitious goals which promotes hard work

Title: Lives up to the hype
Pro: Impact, scale, the learning, tools, smart coworkers, the perks (free food!), reputation / resume name value, the compensation, internal mobility.
Con: Work-life balance can be a challenge. Also sometimes hard to not feel overshadowed if you're not a SWE. Overall though it's awesome.

Title: Good so far
Pro: Perks: Food, good pay, lots of events and technical challenges, smart coworkers, interesting work, lots of different types of tech, cutting edge tech
Con: Compared to most places, there are no real cons to speak of

Title: Great place to grow and make impact
Pro: Individuals are empowered to make impact via autonomy.  Managers care about employees and help them grow.  Great place to grow your career.  Smart and kind coworkers.
Con: Bay Area traffic to MPK sucks.  Tough year for FB.

Title: I was working at Facebook full-time
Pro: A good place to be in.  Enjoyed my full potential. work and life are balanced.
Con: You have to be able to manage upwards and downwards and stressful sometimes.

Title: Amazing place to work for the right set of people
Pro: Ability to chose team and what to work on. Ability to define direction and vision. At time feels like an internal start-up inside a giant company
Con: Calibrations are done via peer comparisons and that can be stressful

Title: Amazing
Pro: Coworkers, tough challenges, endless opportunities, fantastic benefits, world travel.
Con: All consuming, easy for overachievers to burn out, some clueless people have snuck in over the past couple of years and we are less prone to firing them as we were in the past.

Title: Sweet place to work
Pro: Huge impact, Smart peers, Good food, and Hard technical challenges to list a few. I also really like the culture.
Con: Noise and distractions in an open work environment sometimes hurts productivity sometimes. Luckily, there are couches and quiet rooms for that.

Title: Best working place for engineers
Pro: Everything is set up great and convenient. People are all easy going and collaborative. I don't see politics here and people grow based on their performance and contribution. Of course there are great free food everyday!

Best CEO

Title: Very informative learning experience for early entry post-graduates.
Pro: One of the most recognizable companies in the business, laid-back, high influx of determined/capable young professionals.
Con: The compensation was a bit lower than I felt it should have been.

Title: Production Engineering
Pro:
Huge breadth and depth you can choose to work in
mix of feature development and ops work, free to focus on either or both.
scale of systems is truly enormous
Con:
Work life balance varies widely between teams.
some teams PE works with can be filled with divas.

Title: The honeymoon never ends at FB!
Pro: Facebook has a great culture and even better values. They encourage their employees to be bold, move fast and be their true selves at work.
Con: No complaints or cons with FB

Title: Referrals Program Specialist
Pro:
Great company to work with and will stay as long as possible!
Very positive culture here and will recommend to all my friends and family!
Con: I believe we can do better at the compensation and benefits. Especially thinking about the living-cost around the neighborhood.

Title: Performance Review is a single point of failure (SPOF)
Pro: Good Salary, friendly coworkers, a lot of benefit like free food, free wash.
Con: Work life balance is so bad. Average 50 hours+ per week.

Title: Toxic culture
Pro: Good salary, great benefits, good brand to have in your resume
Con: Toxic culture. Poorly designed performance reviews that lead to a competitive environment and people working towards getting a better assessment, not building better products.

Title: Best work of your career
Pro: You get to work on the most fulfilling challenges with colleagues who are great at what they do
Con: There is a high volume of communications

Title: Great team environment and culture!
Pro:
Awesome benefits and pay.
Great teams to work with.
Your opinion matters and is heard.
Difference is accepted, being yourself truly is encourage!
Feel blessed to work for this company!
Con: It can get really busy at time, but you get through it as a team!

Title: Great place to learn, but tough to get behind the mission
Pro:
Resources of a top notch research university
Incredibly smart people
Culture of learning and curiosity
Con:
If you're not on a product/engineering team, you're treated as a different tier of employee
Contract workers are not treated well. That needs to improve.

Title: Amazing, Inspiring, Challenging, and Open
Pro: Amazing perks (food, travel, cloths, vacation, stock..). Smart people working on inspiring and challenging problems. Salary and equity.
Con: Some see a lack of guidance as a con since your will not be micromanaged my your manager and are expected to create your own impact

Title: The best place I have worked at so far
Pro: Coming from Amazon I cannot even dare to write all the pros as it will be a very long list.
Con: I haven't seen any so far.

Title: Best place to work
Pro: Amazing agency in your work and tons of exciting things to work on. Culture is awesome as well.
Con: Not many. I suppose one could be that most teams work long hours.

Title: Amazing place to work
Pro:
- great mentorship
- many opportunities to grow
- challenging
- a lot of benefits
Con:
- extremely high expectations
- stressful
- heard stories of many interns crying during the internship

Title: Amazing place to work
Pro: Culture is carefully engineered to be a great place to work. Engineers are given great benefits and compensation, a lot of autonomy, and a lot of resources to grow.
Con: Very few, as long as you diligently maintain your own work-life boundaries.

Title: Project Manager
Pro: Great opportunity to deliver strongly customer oriented service to market. huge number of talented and creative colleges to build an innovative solution
Con: need to take an initiative activity and mindset to drive other people and motivate subordinate staffs. self starter highly needed

Title: Great place
Pro: Everything is better than any other place I have worked
Con: High pressure environment - you need to perform every week, work through holidays, christmass, new year, and weekends.

Title: Recruiter salary at Facebook
Pro: Depending on the level the salary changes.
Con: Too much work pressure and no work life balance for recruiters

Title: Best company to work for
Pro: Great benefits, great pay,  highly encourages  creativity, rewards productivity.
Con: Non that i can think of at this moment

Title: Fast Paced
Pro:
Love the fast pace of the company
Lots of perks (401k, free food, therapy, 21 days PTO, WFH once a week, ...)
Weekly Q&As with Mark
You get to work with smart people
Con: Focused on short term impact for evaluation during performance reviews every 6 months

Title: Outstanding company - Tasking work but they take care of you. Coming from a guy that never leaves a review for anything!
Pro: They really care about employee welfare! Very impressive.
Con: The job can be very demanding and stressful most time and expectations are very high.

Title: Great Place to work
Pro: Best Tech Company to work, open and warm people. You are always pushed harder and with a raised bar
Con: Over crowded campus, constant pressure, constant change and re org

Title: Good Company
Pro:
- Good Pay
- Competitive Benefit
- Lots of freedom in choosing teams and projects. Wide variety of projects
- Less bureaucracy than some other older companies
Con:
- Bad PR affects morale
- Could be quite cut-throat
- Things are moving slower with more politics than it used to

Title: Love it here!
Pro: Amazing community, very encouraging, inclusive, and great room for growth. I am pushed to be better and better.
Con: A lot of people - which I love, but can be a smidge overwhelming. Everyone is inclusive and welcoming though so not really overwhelming.

Title: amazing
Pro: it is rthe best place to work on this earth probably thwe best employer for te century. that is the best complement i can give to a company in palo alto,claifornia,USA,North America,Earth,Solar System,Milky Way Galaxy.
Con: i cant say anything about that because  i personally feel that this is avery good comapny s o personally no downsides for working at facebook.

Title: Overly focused on engineers, cut-throat
Pro:
+excellent benefits
+"fun" environment
+fun outings and events
Con:
-for entry level positions in customer service/operations, etc., very little room for growth
-although company culture is fun, strong feeling of preps +sorority girls in sales
-

Title: inspired to be part of this team
Pro: amazing brilliant people, great morale, tremendous perks, amazing product, so much room for the company to grow...we are changing the world
Con: the work is so interesting it can become difficult to disconnect

Title: Best culture, top compensation, amazing talent
Pro:
Well paid
Working with talented people
The culture - it is unbelievable - hacker culture
Con: Working hard, long hours... if you like what you do - it is fun.  Otherwise - not so much!

Title: Product Designer
Pro: By far the best place to work. Benefits are generous and design problems are challenging. People are friendly.
Con: The company is HUGE. The most challenging part is keeping up with all the changes happening to the company.

Title: Facebook gives the flexibility to take chances and choose to focus on what you feel will have the most impact
Pro: Great benefits, company makes you feel wanted and valued
Con: Flexibility also means you are fully responsible if your work doesn’t have impact

Title: Awesome place to work as an engineer
Pro:
I worked here as a Software Engineer intern.
- Great engineering culture (likely best in the world)
- Great software engineers
- Great perks
- Great work-life balance
- Great projects
- Great management
Con: Nothing comes to mind right now.

Title: Best company I ever worked for
Pro:
- Build products fast
- Wide range of skilled people from all over the world
- You can do many many things there
- Work for/with Mark
- free food
- perks (sports)
Con: #NAME?

Title: Amazing place to work
Pro: Incredible growth and still focused on impact and success, despite increasing company size
Con: High pressure to succeed, increasing company size no longer really feels like a startup

Title: Awesome work environment
Pro: Facebook encourages each and every employee to make impact and gives you the freedom in which to do your job and encourages you to handle new projects to grow yourself.
Con: No cons really that I can think of..

Title: I've gained 20 pounds working here
Pro: Perks, wages, brilliant engineers, and lots of cool cutting edge technology.
Con: Work life balance? What's that????

Title: Just starting, but everything has been a dream so far
Pro: Everything seems too good to be true, but I haven't heard anybody stating that it ever ends
Con: Absolutely nothing so far, granted it hasn't been long.

Title: Phenomenal
Pro: Super helpful co-workers, nice engineering tools and infrastructure, very little process in the way
Con: You end up spending a lot of time working (without noticing!)

Title: Facebook in review from new york
Pro: Great collaborative atmosphere. Always feel supported
Con: A lot of ambition and high expectations from leadership

Title: The Best Job Out There
Pro: Incredible people. Mission driven. Tons of autonomy to make an impact.
Con: Massive growth has slightly slowed down the ability to get things done as quickly as we were once able to.

Title: Amazing Company to work for
Pro: They care about their employees, have a competitive compensation and benefits package and you don't feel like you are working for a big corporation.
Con: No offices, all open space and it is hard to find a conference room available

Title: Positive experience overall; good choice compare to most companies, and probably one of the best in large companies.
Pro:
Good culture overall. Good career path for my personal experience. 
Very good benefits
Con: Loose some sharpness in execution when team gets bigger

Title: Overachievers Wanted
Pro: Free food, smart people, potential to work on impactful products
Con: Unclear expectations, burnout rate is high

Title: Recruiter
Pro: Moving fast, awesome culture, smart people, rooftop garden, manager training, sweet stop, and music around campus cafes.
Con: Can't really pinpoint anything to complain about. I mean after all, we have amazing benefits!

Title: Software engineer
Pro: Great work place. I can learn a lot. Nice coworkers. Great benefits. Reasonable work hours. I would recommend working here.
Con: A lot of responsibility. Things move super fast. This is pretty much i. It is overall a great place to work

Title: Product Manager
Pro: Great place to work and have a successful career. People care about what they do. Benefits are awesome and love working here.
Con: Work pressure can creep up sometime. Org changes can happen often. However, this is all part of growing pain.

Title: Software Engineer
Pro: Awesome company. Tons of opportunities and challenges. Best compensation and culture in the industry.
Con: Every engineer, regardless of level, works more independently than most other companies, which can be a challenge for people fresh out of college with no industry experience.

Title: Great place to work
Pro: Super smart and hardworking people, great company culture, wonderful perks & pay. I get to do great work and then go home and relax. This was a great job to land post-PhD!
Con: I have no particular cons to share

Title: Awesome Place to Work
Pro: great, smart  people, loads of autonomy
Con: I sincerely can't think of anything. I wish the real estate weren't so expensive on the Peninsula.

Title: Technical Sourcer
Pro: Thorough interview.  Good blend of past experience an sourcing knowledge.  Conversational but professional.  Able to get a strong understanding of team dynamic and measures of success.
Con: Unclear what the conversion to full time process is, how long it takes.

Title: Awesome
Pro: Great place to work, great salary, great food, laid back atmosphere.
Con: Not much in the way of cons here. We get everything we need.

Title: Great company in general, but too big now if you are looking for a startup
Pro: Passionate and smart people; company brand value; lots of different projects/areas to work on
Con: it's becoming more like a big company now

Title: Excellent
Pro: Good pay, excellent environment, tons of perks, opportunity to work with several teams, beautiful office, Opportunities for mobility within the company, everyone feels like they're on the same team
Con: repetetive work, cult-ish, but only if you feel that way,

Title: Simply the best
Pro: A mission driven company that always stands behind its mission. Very transparent culture and excellent management
Con: Biggest issue I see is burn out but the company is focused on this particular problem in an incredibly thoughtful way

Title: A good place to work at
Pro: A lot of good engineers and a lot of good engineering problems. It makes a good environment to learn and grow
Con: It's big enough that there is significant differences in engineering culture within the company.

Title: Inspired to do your best work
Pro: competitive salary, outstanding peer set, great benefits
Con: growing fast making it hard to maintain the culture

Title: Take the Fire Hose literely
Pro: Working Environment, Benefits, mission statement, training and education, Free Food. The Team
Con: Strains on infrastructure and local communities keeps growing as we do.

Title: Amazing culture. Super excited
Pro: Can not ask for better. Amazing. Great. Work life balance. On top of all companies I worked for.
Con: Did not see any yet.

Title: Volunteering at FB TechStart
Pro:
Amazing people and opportunities within the program
Gets you involved with the tech environment and coorporations, including Facebook itself. 
Great for growing experience, knowing people, and feeling self-rewarded for helping others.
Con: none, it was an amazing experience.

Title: Best company i've ever worked for
Pro: Culture, Culture, Culture, Food, Culture
Con: Over emphasized sales org, product sells itself. Needed to value other pillars more than they were

Title: Senior Technical Program Manager
Pro: Great Benefits both at work and for families like Medical/Dental/Vision/401k.  Generous work related support in terms of services, food, etc.
Con: Zero concern for actual professional work environments.  Constant personal and work life blending:  Result feels like a forced exposure which may or may not align with your core values.  Protected class employees and potential employees valued over non-protected classes uniformly in terms of skills/experience and relevance.

Title: Great Company, Blurred Internal Mobility
Pro:
Perks
Pay
Flexibility
People
Resources (Career Development and Self)
Con:
A lot of information/ information overload
Also a pro - requiring a master skill of prioritization
Extremely social business with some politics

Title: Great place to work
Pro: Really appreciated their response to COVID, I truly feel like this company cares for it's employees.
Con: Can be a bit organizationally confusing, especially for a new hire, but people tend to be very open and supportive

Title: The best place to work, period.
Pro: 3 meals + snack a day. Micro kitchens with fresh fruit, boxed lunches, and every beverage imaginable. All free. Flexible work hours, work from home, 21 days of PTO.
Con: In Palo Alto, CA -- a bit suburban for city dwellers.

Title: Great work environment and culture
Pro: Autonomy to work on challenging problems at scale
Con: Some growing pains to be expected at company of this stage

Title: Loving every minute of it!
Pro: Fast paced, lots of very committed and competent people around me. Company is dedicated to innovation and wants to do good in the world.
Con: Change of environment (Unix -> Windows) can make people less productive in the short term.

Title: Awesome perks, smart co-workers, great environment for engineers
Pro:
- Really good perks
- Challenging yet fun work environment. Engineers have a lot of say in the product.
Con: The company is getting bigger day by day.

Title: Awesome!
Pro: Excellent environment. A huge number of perks, including 4-month paternity leave, free food, occasional home office, etc. It feels great to work on products 1.5 billion people use.
Con: They could be more organized when managing and planning projects

Title: Software Engineer
Pro: Great culture, great people to work with! Move fast and provides the freedom to choose team, project based on interest and advantage.
Con: Moves faster and busier than other companies at the same scale.

Title: Great Culture
Pro: Highly collaborative, smart people, mission driven company, fun colleagues, fast moving, energetic
Con: At times, lack of focus...placing too many bets and not quick enough to abandon some and focus on ones that are showing early success

Title: Great culture. Visionary CEO. Inspiring COO.
Pro: Great culture overall. Good benefits. Smart people.
Con: As the company has grown, the functions have become siloed with less autonomy on decision making.

Title: Great workplace
Pro:
Autonomy and freedom to work on projects you're interested in
Great bootcamp training
Everyone is incredibly intelligent and executes well
Con: Starting to get fairly bureaucratic, even in 2015. Can't imagine now but I've heard it has only gotten worse.

Title: Amazed doesn’t begin to describe it
Pro: Great pay, great benefits, beautiful campus, so many great minds all in one place.
Con: Can’t think of any, when you love what you do and where you work.

Title: Best Company to work for
Pro: Countless perks and benefits, challenging and exciting subject matter, treated with respect by peers and managers, excellent career growth opportunities
Con: Work-life balance can be challenging when you want to perform well and exceed expectations

Title: Great company
Pro: Smartest people I’ve ever worked with. Smartest leadership I’ve ever worked for.
Con: It’s so big it’s easy to feel like a small fish in a big pond.

Title: Amazing experience
Pro: Lots of perks, fulfilling projects that only a few companies in the world are working on
Con: Your experience largely depends on the team. After three years thats the biggest decider of experience

Title: Fantastic culture that inspires authenticity and your best work
Pro: Intelligence Authenticity Fast pace Employee oriented
Con: Still a start-up culture which has many pros but getting things done takes networking

Title: Committed to its mission
Pro: Well articulated mission, values, philosophies. Committed to the mission of providing people with tools to build communities. Strong leadership, Great onboarding program. Friendly people.
Con: Could be thrifty. There are probably many opportunities to save costs.

Title: Spoiled rotten, and rewarded for impact
Pro: For a large company, it's amazing how they have quantified the ability to measure and quantify contributions as a metric towards career advancement.
Con: Advancements in career tend to promote building new systems over advancement of existing systems.

Con: High expectations so working hard is essential to succeed.

Title: Fantastic workplace for motivated employees

Pro: The best part of Facebook is the culture and how everyone is trying to build something great.
Con: The pitfall of Facebook is that it's so large and that it treats its contingent workforce like a step-child.

Title: Unforgettable experience
Pro: There is a strong sense of decency and morality pulsing throughout the culture.  Leadership is genuine, inspiring and accessible.
Con: Allegiance to culture and company creates a bubble where differing viewpoints are difficult to identify and discuss.

People spend more time socializing n selling their nonescence work more than work itself. On top of that no proper documentation any where as they play their social media game. No collaboration or visibility among team members no body knows what his team mate works on. Aggression between employees for claiming credit at PsC. The louder voice wins. Seriously wascexpecting better. Could not imagine the amount of sickness in that environment.

Title: Great perks, great pay | Risky market perception in Nov 2022
Pro: Developer productivity is given great importance. There's dedicated org for ensuring developers are highly productive, ironing out latency issues in VS Code, building new extensions for flagging syntactical issues, lint issues, exceptions, latency / performance issues [all within VSCode]. All this means time to write code is dramatically reduced [no worry about spinning up new instance, provisioning distributed machines, setting up development machines, etc] It's a great company in terms of perks, despite broad macro-economic downturn - we have £2500 wellness benefit and £2600 travel benefit, pension match upto 6% employee [9% employer contribution] with Fidelity, great insurance [level 4 with cigna for dentist & WPA for health]
Con: Low value of RSU - negatively affects total compensation [stock component] Market doesn't believe in potential of meta-verse.

Title: Great perks, great pay | Risky market perception in Nov 2022
Pro: Developer productivity is given great importance. There's dedicated org for ensuring developers are highly productive, ironing out latency issues in VS Code, building new extensions for flagging syntactical issues, lint issues, exceptions, latency / performance issues [all within VSCode]. All this means time to write code is dramatically reduced [no worry about spinning up new instance, provisioning distributed machines, setting up development machines, etc] It's a great company in terms of perks, despite broad macro-economic downturn - we have £2500 wellness benefit and £2600 travel benefit, pension match upto 6% employee [9% employer contribution] with Fidelity, great insurance [level 4 with cigna for dentist & WPA for health]
Con: Low value of RSU - negatively affects total compensation [stock component] Market doesn't believe in potential of meta-verse.

Title: Great Benefit but It will Cost Your Mental Health
Pro: Amazing benefit overpaying the employees almost doubled than what the market pays
Con: You will not be involved in decision making, strategic planning for your job. You will basically just execute whatever task was given to you. You can involved in a lot of projects if you are volunteering and always put yourself forward. But again, this will feel repetitive and a lot of people comes out with useless projects just so that they outshine others. Team culture is very different from each team. You cant expect a 80k employees company to have the same culture throughout. Always speak to your direct team and managers before signing the offer. I can tell you that some team are unbearable. I am glad to have spoken to my manager before hand and choose the right one. But during my interview, I rejected the initial offer as I was speaking to some spiteful manager. The latest layoff, I see that the leadership team (C suite) didnt properly manage the process. There's a lot of frustration happens. My colleagues that we laid off up until the day it was announced, there's a lot of mis step. Decision was taken mainly due to the pressure from greedy shareholders as the Q3 revenue doesnt seems alarming as what mentioned by the leadership as well. I would say that, if you got job offer from Meta, if you are looking for a place that would provide better lifestyle especially in a short span, then definitely take it. But if you want to grow in a team that truly appreciate your opinion and voice, definitely avoid at all cause as they also ill informed the managers and made it very hard for leaders and managers to manage team's expectation

Title: Nightmare
Pro: Meta offers many great perks, as with the Tech companies.
Con:
Do not mistaken the Singapore  Data Centre to be the Tech Giant Meta. They are totally different. 

- The management in data centre does not embody Meta culture. The culture in data centre is worse than small medium enterprises. Employees are expected to be yes men, not to raise any questions or even provide feedback. You'll be targeted by management and your performance appraisal will suffer. 

- In the data centre, many perks given by Meta are not applicable to you if you are not a manager. Management said you are not to "take advantage of the company " so don't assume the perks such as Global travel days, or even claims of mileage for work purpose to be allowed. They will be rejected by your line manager.

- Overall culture is non-supportive and toxic with no flexibility. Expected to work in site office 5 days a week.

- Data centre hired people who aren't very competent or capable. It's really puzzling , guess the loop interview is not working. 

- No career progress, almost impossible to get promoted.

- Meta prides itself as a company that supports diversity but the Data centre is a strong supporter of CECA.

- Avoid at all costs unless you are a yes man.

Title: Great people. but backstabbing
Pro: Great people around. The best I've ever met! Super ambitious goals. Great benefits. WFH flexibility.
Con:
Performance review. It works this way:

1. Leadership escalate project X
2. You clearly don't see any impact of X, but has to disagree and commit
3. You give the project to an eng from your team (even if they disagree)
4. Eng executes the project
5. PSC comes. And eng does not receive credit for X because, guess what, no impact

And this loop happens again and again. You build a special skill how to dodge from this crappy non impactful projects.

Title: Great people. but backstabbing
Pro: Great people around. The best I've ever met! Super ambitious goals. Great benefits. WFH flexibility.
Con:
Performance review. It works this way:

1. Leadership escalate project X
2. You clearly don't see any impact of X, but has to disagree and commit
3. You give the project to an eng from your team (even if they disagree)
4. Eng executes the project
5. PSC comes. And eng does not receive credit for X because, guess what, no impact

And this loop happens again and again. You build a special skill how to dodge from this crappy non impactful projects.

Title: Great opportunity to work on cool products with smart people, difficult to move internally
Pro:
Amazing place to learn and grow (trains you very well in leadership, data driven decision making, industry best practices, technical knowledge)
The people are generally very smart and creative, there can be a lot of grass roots problem solving and collaboration which can be very fun and energising
There are very smart people to learn from, with a strong management and mentoring culture which means it's easy to find strong sponsors and mentors who are genuinely invested in your growth
The perks and compensation are great, it's a difficult place to leave
The culture is highly transparent and logic driven, there is a genuine desire to do the right thing under highly complex circumstances where the trade offs are immense. People aren't afraid to challenge and there's often healthy discussion
Con:
Highly optimised for individual impact, which can be very empowering but also lead to some bias towards short term thinking (which the company is addressing)
Priorities shift very quickly which means vision, strategy and org structure are constantly evolving and changing. It's a wild ride which teaches you a lot but can be difficult when driven by a mission for it to be ever changing
Product Operations department has some very strong people and is a great place to learn due to variety, high expectations and need to lead and influence to be successful, however progression is not guaranteed and can feel challenging to reach the common career progression milestones (e.g. promotions). The combination of a low ceiling and many talented people means it's highly competitive
It can be challenging to move internally from operations to tech due to many bureaucratic  barriers that don't feel well aligned with ability and experience of the individual

Title: A lot is expected from you, but they also give you a lot
Pro: Salary, benefits, multicultural environment, open and constant attention around minorities (LGBTQIA+, women, black, asian etc), innovative view, low hierarchy structure, you can grow within the company
Con:
the company move fast, you need to move fast with it. 
A lot is given to the employees so the company expects a lot in return.
Working-life balance can be challenging depending on your Manager and where your Team is based (US, Europe and/or Asia --> meeting can be quite early and/or quite late following the different time-zones). 
Performance are generally evaluated not (or not only) based on specific goals, but also based on what your colleagues from the same team on a global level have achieved compared to you (kind of benchmark performance review). So maybe your goal was X and you do X+10, but most of your teammates achieve X+30, so you can get a "doesn't meet expectations" on your review. And because of this, the environment tends to be more and more competitive (which maybe for someone can be a "pros")

Title: Good Benefits, Too Woke
Pro: Meta pays top dollar among FAANG companies and is a great place to work with really good benefits. Dev environment is really good and internal tools help me work faster. Growth here is crazy. You can get promoted from E3 to E5 in 2 years. Mark has a Company wide QnA every week.
Con: The new privacy improvements have slowed engineering down and constant exaggerated scandals cause my income to fluctuate (because of stock price fluctuations). There’s a lot of woke-ism as is typical for FAANG and I feel it overshadows product development, but I do see the long term communal benefits of investing in these initiatives. There is no official pressure to perform, but there is peer pressure.

Title: Great for a few years, tought on the long run.
Pro: Working with loads of smart people is great, you learn a lot. Benefits & perks are good.
Con:
Over time there's this pressure to over perform beyond your level, with removal of bonus: there's the expectation that you should always be delivering more and more, to get the same bonus. This becomes unhearthy, as work and life balance suffers, pressure increases and you end up receiving less compensation for what's essentially the same work.

Also, there's a MASSIVE disconnect between "everything proprietary internal" and "the real world", so the longer you work for the company, the more distant you are from skills and tools that'll use at your next job, as most of what was learned, is essentially lost.

Stocks compensation also decreases with time, which is another driver to "only stay a few years".

Title: Great package, superficial culture
Pro: Salary, benefits, challenging work, transparency
Con:
So much change that there never seems to be a clear direction of travel. A lot of work goes to waste as a result.
HR run this company and have no room for edge cases or common sense in their policy application.
Constant negativity surrounding the company makes it very hard to feel a sense of pride working here
Promotions are lagging so increased scope does not correlate to career progression or salary increase. The company without doubt takes as much advantage of this as possible.
Internal moves are lateral only, if you are successful for an internal role you will not be promoted into it even if it is a more senior role.

Title: WhatsApp is So So
Pro:
1. People
2. Salary
3. Stock
4. Work Environment (When actually at the office)
Con:
1. Leadership are mishmash and slow to implement meaningful change
2. Lots of "ladder climbers" who have total disregard to everyone else and the company itself
3. The level of care on work/life balance is really poor, especially during the pandemic
4. Performance rating is not totally balanced and can be unfair for anyone who is working in "new product" territories
5. Movement up is non existent. They are desperate for people to join the WA vertical, but eventually after a year or 2, people move either out of the company or to FB/Instagram/Workplace
6. FB makes a lot of "Right Wing" decisions with public facing issues. Staff worry that the brand rep is only getting worse and impacts other products like WA and Insta. Deal making gets harder

Title: Great company. Will go through lots of changes in the months ahead.
Pro:
1. Expect lots of wonderful, smart and friendly people 
2. Travel to different facebook offices and overseas offsites
3. Good ecommerce and retailer linkage
4. Lots of internal resources and materials
5. Great food, snacks, wonderful insurance coverage, paternity and maternity leave
6. Plenty of avenues to highlight your good work and show and tell
Con:
1. Big company with inefficiencies
2. Staff benefits could be better, compared to other industries (transport, flexi, etc) 
3. Not all managers will lead, mentor or protect the team. Manager encountered saw most feedbacks as problems, rather than understanding reasons that led to this (politics, gaps from org changes, etc) and solving it with you. 
4. Sharing with clients that KPI is not tied to sales. When feedbacks from sales team are most crucial to performance reviews. 
5. Advertising is the main source of revenue. 
6. Too many product changes in the past months. Clients may not be able to keep up or as interested to do so

Title: Bad direction, no critical feedback of first-time managers
Pro:
Overall compensation
Top tech kit
Some areas are very promising
Con:
When joining, I picked Shops because it was a promising project, but after I made my decision, it was clear that the Org was notoriously disorganised. The project has lost most of its key personnel because the Director for Product was unable to give a clear direction, and censored all the reasonable ideas. My manager was inexperienced and refused to hear any suggestion that I made. It felt really demoralising and frustrating. I reached out to other managers, friends from previous job who agreed that it was frustrating… but that’s it.
– I agree, this is a horrible situation.
– What can I do about it?
– I don’t know…
– Wait a year, so I can change teams?
– Maybe. That was changed to 18 months though.

All three of the Org, the project and my manager had "the worst Pulse rating in the history of the company" at their level, according to people who had been at Facebook longer. No one reached out.

Several key stakeholders left, notably one senior Data engineer. I offered to take over some of their workload because I knew how and I badly needed data to do my own work. That was yet another suggestion that my manager shut down.

It got tiring really fast.

Title: Prefer the Software Engineer role instead
Pro:
Good benefits 
Work Culture is good in most of the aspects
Free food
Travel to different facebook offices
Talented and Ambitious peers, push you to grow
Con:
While the overall experience at Facbooks is reasonably good, depending on the team, quality of projects/work may vary from excellent to pathetic. 
Need to bargain hard on your CTC while joining the company to safeguard your interests. Managers have absolutely NO say in your compensation and wont be able to help you even if you perform well.
One should always interview for the Software Engineer position, which has slightly better pay, more opportunities to move around, different (better?) evaluation standards!

If you end up in a team which has no clear charter, you are expected to find your own work while the managers would not support you with this

Work life balance is average at best. You are expected to work a lot and it is more so if you want to grow to higher levels.In my opinion, people who have a strong career growth, don't have much time left and burnout often.

Title: Still a great place to work
Pro: Work hard at keeping remote working people connected. Generous support for remote workers. Great support for flexible hours focus on work delivery. Try hard for "fairness" in bi-annual assessments. Pretty independent salary setting method means you are not completely at the whim of your relationship with your boss although your bosses support in presenting your performance twice a year is a major contributor to your grading. This in turn drives your pay rise, chance of upgrading your level, and, the percentage bonus your granted. There is also a formula based calculation that determines what stock value you may receive as a top-up refresher to your stocks granted when joining. This too is linked to performance. Employees who drive hard and perform well all the time supporting their peers tend to get well rewarded (as they should be!)
Con: As with many rapidly expanding businesses, some people can find themselves with a different manager each year. Difficult for relationship building and targets agreement. Drive to target performance review scores can get in the way of common sense sometimes. Some policy implementations can come across as harsh. There are structures imposed on how you can make promotion steps that work against job retention.

Title: Empowering mission-driven work.  Driving positive societal changes everyday.
Pro: Facebook prioritises building positive social impact. They do this over growing revenue and this creates a hugely incredible mission-driven company. You are empowered to align personal and team goals to invent the products and outcomes to build social good. Every person that you work with at Facebook has this mindset, creating an incredibly supportive and collaborative environment where everyone is an ally.
Con: Facebook isn't for everyone. The hardest thing that many people struggle with is the amount of ownership and accountability you are given. Because Facebook is so bottoms-up, it requires people to be able to be highly collaborative to gather information to make the right decision. No one is going to tell you what to work on, you have to decide yourself what will be most impactful. That's a hard environment to be successful in for many.

Title: Great place to work
Pro:
I have been super happy at Facebook in Dublin, my manager has always been very understanding and helping in every way possible, the Danish team is a great team and my manager helped me a lot to pursue what I wanted within my position. I would love to work with my manager and team again, however I had to leave FB due to missing opportunities in-market and no option for remote work as I have travelled back to my home country due to personal reasons. 

I would always recommend Facebook as a good place to work, you will get:

- Great colleagues 
- Great managers
- Amazing culture within your team
- Great perks
- Strong work/life balance
- Many options to explore new skills
- Many team offsite events (before covid)
- Trip to San Francisco every year
Con:
- Performance evaluation is very long and takes too much time
- In-market job opportunities are rare and hard to get

Title: Just operations. Zero innovation.
Pro: It's interesting to see how FB operates.
Con: I was promised a role at the intersection of tech leadership, product strategy and people management. But it was nothing like that at all. I essentially spent 100% of my time doing operational things that I didn't enjoy, like following bureaucratic processes. Directions for the team were set from the top. People are moved around like pawns because of frequent reorgs. Everyone behaved like a career-obsessed robots, always looking for ways to game PSCs. But the most frustrating feeling of all was that I didn't see anyone try to innovate in any way. All the products efforts that I witnessed were either about copying a competitor or leveraging/abusing FB's dominant position in some market to push features to users (in a way that always serves FB's interest first and the user's interest second).

Title: Amazing place to work - Nordic Scaled account manager
Pro:
Worked at Facebook Dublin, sales/account management for the Nordics market, team called Nordic Scaled. I have nothing but good things to say about the team, managers and upper management. 

- The team culture is very supportive, leaving room for development. Further, the team is young, talented, curious and entrepreneurial - creating a fun environment to work in. 

- I had multiple different managers within the Nordic team, all were seeking to understand my needs, supporting my development. I always felt very valued, listened to and could talk to my managers about anything. 

- You get the chance to take on high responsibility straight away, such as consulting mid-large size business in the digital marketing space. Or to take on internal projects, with real impact. 

- Great opportunity to develop yourself and your skills through; Coaching from managers, mentorship programs, training sessions, lectures etc. 

- No micro management, managers trust that you deliver good work and coach if needed. 

- Work Life Balance is great! Yes, the goals could be tough from time to time and new joiners might feel that it is a lot to learn the first few months. Your manager will encourage and enable you to not work late. Also, everyone is encouraged to go work out during office hours, (Pre-covid there were regular group sessions with Facebook to go work out if you wanted to). Also, no one expects that you sit late in the office.
Con:
- Sometimes tough to see your impact/contribution in an organization of this size and turnover. 

- Things move fast and what is your goal one day might need to change the other. 

- A bit American centralized, meaning that conversations around polici

Title: Fast moving, fun, humble people
Pro:
There’s no where like Facebook. I’m surrounded by talented yet friendly and humble people. The culture is strong, we have a clear mission and values. 
- Allow you to lean into your strengths and this makes work enjoyable. 
- I can make impact quickly. 
- My manger is supportive and open.
- Growth oriented, always options to learn including L&D and mentors.
- Travel was amazing when we could! 
- Incredible benefits including generous holidays, bonuses, equipment, health, parental leave.
- Best in Class review system- it’s peer led and official reviews happen twice per year.
- Inclusive culture. Lots of ERGs.

This company looked after me better than I could of dreamed during Covid. Received many supports including money and flexible working.
Con: Negative press cycles, Facebook is in the eye of the media and much of the good for the world work isn’t covered.

Pro: The company really takes good care of the employees. People are constantly looking out for each other and making sure no one feels left along. The company has a very open culture and the management will explain the motivation of a policy and decision in deepth, so that everyone is on the same page and for better buy in. The perks are fantastic -- it surely is the best I have received and I think it might be the best in the local market too.
Con: It is still a very clearly US-central company. For all meetings and townhalls, it is all held in US timing. I have colleagues who is not willing to have meetings after their office hours so they propose timing during Asia sleeping time...

Title: Excellent people / inclusive culture
Pro: People are really nice. So helpful that its almost unreal. Onboarding even during Covid times where its WFH, the people actually make time for you and are willing to help you with something that may be totally outside his / her area of expertise or JD. Being a large company, it has people from variety of religions, ethnicity, etc., etc., etc., (we cant say enough of those things). However, here it feels all the same. Being different is celebrated and welcomed. Being your own self is the way here.
Con: The company revolves around its people. I feel that could be a downside as people leave at some point. So, its better to have set systems in place. Again, this may not be entirely possible for this company because of the pace at which it moves.

Title: Just operations. Zero innovation.
Pro: It's interesting to see how FB operates.
Con: I was promised a role at the intersection of tech leadership, product strategy and people management. But it was nothing like that at all. I essentially spent 100% of my time doing operational things that I didn't enjoy, like following bureaucratic processes. Directions for the team were set from the top. People are moved around like pawns because of frequent reorgs. Everyone behaved like a career-obsessed robots, always looking for ways to game PSCs. But the most frustrating feeling of all was that I didn't see anyone try to innovate in any way. All the products efforts that I witnessed were either about copying a competitor or leveraging/abusing FB's dominant position in some market to push features to users (in a way that always serves FB's interest first and the user's interest second).

Pulse results are analysed for ICs to ensure fixes are put in place, but as a manger no one ever questions if they can make your work life better.

Title: Challenging workplace
Pro: Very smart people who cultivate a culture of excellence. Good perks
Con:
You have to use Atlas which is kind of internal Facebook for organisations, in this Atlas you have to publish posts about the projects you work on. 
The amount of likes, shares and comments your internal post gets impact your evaluation and your rating. 
You have to conduct self-assessment every 6 months (which is fine per-se) however you must provide 5 colleagues at least that will fill their opinion over your performances. The craziest thing is that you don't get to see their feedback and learn about it only from your manager.

The HR in the Tel Aviv office is very problematic, they have difficulties understanding what Program Managers do and it's quite daunting working with them.

Title: Dangerous Cult DNA
Pro: Most skillful engineers in the country
Con: In my position I had a lot of influence in hiring and terminating employees. I have being exposed to dubious decisions in that area by upper management, actions taken without good-heart and with conflicts of interest. This behavior could only thrive in our Cult-like company where truly speaking out your mind could hurt your career. Quite ironically, the values of giving constant feedback are encouraged in Facebook, but in reality, employees are afraid of giving negative feedback as they know the potential devastating consequences of doing so. Negative feedback will be given about technical decisions and ideas but not about managerial decisions or the human resource department from fear of upsetting the wrong people.

Title: Mixed Feelings
Pro: Friendly people, friendly managers. Amazing company and products. Excited to be part of such an amazing organization. Friendly work culture and collaboration environment. Very good infrastructure and tooling. Great perks. Good upper management.
Con: Competitive, stressful and high pressure working environment. Subpar communication. Bottom up management is challenging. Middle level program and project management totally lacking. Communication in a COVID-19 WFH environment challenging when the work culture historically was office based. Instability is normal: releasing to production and taking risks is actively encouraged. The codebase is in places low quality. The majority of the documentation is outdated and therefore unusable. High turnover of staff means little continuity; the only people who stay long enough usually end up so stressed that you have to deal with people barely being able to function due to burnout.

Title: Awesome place to work
Pro:
There are so many cool things to say about where I work. I am an ex-Googler and I have had great expeirences in both companies but I would have to honestly say leaving Google to come to Facebook has been the best decision I ever made. 

We are all so busy, there is no time for politics and BS. We are solving huge problems and the work we do is played out on such a huge scale. Having this level of impact and being part of a relatively tiny team means you can really feel the value of the work you do. I love that we do not hyper hire, I love the fact that we hire such great people, people with a sense of purpose and some of the smartest people I have ever had the pleasure to work with. 

WE have great amenities as well. Everything you need is here at the office. People don't mind coming into work, people are genuinely happy to be here and you cannot fake this atmosphere.

Feedback is well received and management do an awesome job of actioning this and listening to employees.
Con:
The salary is not the highest I have ever had but the perks, bonus, annual salary and stock reviews etc make this better and there is an emphasis on performance based increases, so hard work is really well rewarded.

Its a fast moving place which I also love but can be challenging as things we work on can change quickly so you need to be super adaptable but the dynamic nature of the role and the company makes it interesting and never dull.

Title: Awesome place to work
Pro:
There are so many cool things to say about where I work. I am an ex-Googler and I have had great expeirences in both companies but I would have to honestly say leaving Google to come to Facebook has been the best decision I ever made. 

We are all so busy, there is no time for politics and BS. We are solving huge problems and the work we do is played out on such a huge scale. Having this level of impact and being part of a relatively tiny team means you can really feel the value of the work you do. I love that we do not hyper hire, I love the fact that we hire such great people, people with a sense of purpose and some of the smartest people I have ever had the pleasure to work with. 

WE have great amenities as well. Everything you need is here at the office. People don't mind coming into work, people are genuinely happy to be here and you cannot fake this atmosphere.

Feedback is well received and management do an awesome job of actioning this and listening to employees.
Con:
The salary is not the highest I have ever had but the perks, bonus, annual salary and stock reviews etc make this better and there is an emphasis on performance based increases, so hard work is really well rewarded.

Its a fast moving place which I also love but can be challenging as things we work on can change quickly so you need to be super adaptable but the dynamic nature of the role and the company makes it interesting and never dull.

Title: Some hard work needed
Pro:
* Perks: gym coverage, free food, health insurance, snacks (maybe that's a con, I gained loads), public transport pass coverage (you'll need it)
* I've worked with some of the nicest and most engaged hiring managers here that helped solve recruiting challenges 
* Recruiting tools are literally the best in the business.
Con:
* The pressure to perform is insane; hitting my target + delivering on projects was just barely enough to get a meets all during the perf cycle
* Roles are becoming increasingly small and marginalised as the team continues to scale. As a result, you see people jumping (literally) on to projects to set themselves apart from the rest of the team. It makes for a bit of a cut-throat culture just around the time when PSC hits
 * If you're interviewing at facebook, prepare for a ride with R4R - they'll probably won't speak to you again after you've signed the contract
* While there are exceptions, the culture in the recruiting team is just weird. It sort of reminds me of high school. There's cliques, people gossip and there's for sure a couple of bullies: either people wouldn't even say a word to you or would go out of their way to make you feel like you're weird or different (to be honest, that also included my manager).
* Ads Credits & being forced to dog-food beta apps: I'm a huge instagram fan and big user - so being forced to update my apps multiple times a day was a nightmare.
* The perks are nice but salary/bonus are nothing to write home about: base is somewhat competitive but expect around 85-90% of the bonus you're promised in your offer letter.

Title: A workplace with a lot of opportunities
Pro:
- The main reason why working for Facebook is great, is the opportunity to move roles as it allows you to always strive on your ambition and face more interesting challenges. It gives you the opportunity to constantly excel. 
- Another benefit of working
Con: Since you're surrounded by high achievers, you could probably have sleepless nights. Yet this is only to drive yourself and challenge yourself. I wouldn't say it's a complete con, unless you let it affect you very negatively. Because on the other hand we are always encourage to apply work life balance.

Title: Such a great place to work
Pro:
The culture here is fantastic; there are so many things that just work well together. For example, most engineers choose which team to join after the first 6 weeks or so, which encourages a lot of really positive behaviours. The company is also really open, allowing everyone to make great decisions: if you need access to some data, you probably have it available. 

We have good tools and infrastructure that allows us to focus on the important things; things like booking a meeting room, following up on a task in a common system and many other things are just easy, using great tools that an internal team builds and maintains. I also think that the engineering-led approach to product development and a willingness to try things is really special, and allows us to be more bold than most other companies.

Oh, and the free food! Breakfast, lunch and dinner, with lots of great options, both healthy and not-so-healthy.
Con:
It's not a great place if you value being in charge, or being told specifically what to do when. Everyone is expected to be self-led to a large extent.

There also is relatively little documentation. If you want to find out something, most often you need to ask someone rather than read a document.

Title: Amazing Culture
Pro:
Amazing company culture that's embedded in most of its employees. Feedback is done in the most constructive way possible. No BS, genuine attempt to minimize politics (yes no company is 100% politics free), super fast paced, yet respectful of individual time and space. Highly collaborative environment, and everything is measured by impact to people. 

Employees are committed to their works and committed to have fun as well! Most of us are unpretentious or trying to hard to impress or look busy, even though the work is very intense! That's why visitors always thought that we hardly work!

Be warned though, this company may not be for everybody, particularly if your strength revolves around internal politics and bootlicking, or you prefer companies where you can relax and do minimal work, or you don't like to have tough conversations to solve tough problems, or you don't like to work with a team where everybody knows what each other is doing.
Con: Writing this just because I have to, though there's really no cons that I can think of. If I really have to think of something, perhaps it's the amount of interesting information that you have to keep up with everyday.

Title: No complaints
Pro: Good team to work with

Title: a company where I can make impact
Pro: Everyone talks about the amazing perks etc. But that is not the biggest pro. The values are. For me the fact that I can do what I am good at, and really make a a huge impact is absolutely fantastic. Things are going very fast, even with the current company size. Maybe even faster. At Facebook there is a saying that every day is a week, and for me that is true. I think it is very special that moving fast and setting high standards of performance  this can go hand in hand with being really good to employees too.
Con: Keeping up with the pace is sometimes hard, and keeping an overview of all the things that happen. I love our internal groups, and responsive people are to help each other. This at least helps me to speed up on things that matter to me in my job

Title: Toxic culture, work politics at its worst
Pro:
1. Colleagues are smart and you learn a lot from them
2. Good perks and benefits
Con:
1. Everything depends on the whims and fancies of your manager. If you've got a horrible one, beware, you'll be on a leash all your time here.
2. Work culture in the marketing, policy and comms team is super competitive, toxic, isolating and bullying is encouraged.
3. Despite raising concerns to HR about bullying, nothing is done about it and poor managers are rewarded.
4. Company is in an insecure state right now which trickles down to every level of management. Frequent back stabbing, anonymous feedback that harms you and bullying is rampant within teams. 
5. They rely on their ability as the world's largest social media site to get get talented people but do nothing to develop them or encourage honest and fair performance reviews. The PSC process is rigged from the start with low performers getting promoted and actual performers punished for speaking their mind. Its a Yes culture. Don't disagree with anyone if you want to survive here.

Title: Business Integrity
Pro:
Free  Food
Perks
Flexibility 
Salary
Nice Offices
Con:
I worked in Facebook for one year, but my experience in Business Integrity has been literally a nightmare, I felt extremely  underrated,  ignored and not involved in the main team responsibilities. Facebook is for sure a great company, but my experience in BI was really bad. Please, see below the main cons of this team:
 1)Management:  Inexpert management, really superficial and high level approach, luck of clear direction, unprofessional jokes and attitude, play favourites, only interest in their own goals and not the development of the team
- Lack of structure: No processes & structures, many teams have been created without a prior consultant opinion. So many people, me included, have been obliged to work in a team not fitting their skills.
- Not all the opinions are heard: If you try to propose new projects ideas and . process you can result annoying. They ask people of higher level to be independent and drive their own initiatives, but at the end the managers decide and promote only the people that help them to reach their own goals.
- Team collaboration: we are all great talent and characters, but the lack of job together with the managers inconsistency created un-healthy competition and back stubbing environment

Title: A incredible place to work for
Pro: I've been in multiple tech companies so far and I must say that Facebook really does an amazing job at putting its employee in the best position to make them successful. We have the perfect workplace, our career is the main focus of our managers and diversity is not only encourage, but actively advocate (really, the initiative in term of gender equality, the fight against ethnical or confessional based bias here is fuel with so much energy that it should be a standard in modern companies). Also, the well-known CEO really has a plan and is totally transparent about it. I would definitively work here.
Con: Sometimes, I must admit that the all motivational aspect of the culture is a little bit exaggerated, however, most of those great principles "aim higher, don't be afraid to do something..." are actually enforced so, all in all, it is not a big issue and it's align with the company culture.

Title: Awesome perks, awful engineering
Pro: Free food, first class flights to the US, free gadgets and lots and lots of swag. Very complex and difficult problems to solve (mainly self inflicted due to the lack of good endineering practices).
Con:
My experience is in the enterprise engineering org. 
* Very individualistic mindset, team is only the logo on the swag you get.
* Several years of unattended spaghetti engineering that nobody dares to handle, but someone has to maintain (and get burnt doing so). 
* Awful oncalls due to the horrible engineering practices and mountains of tech debt.
* Blame showers during incident reviews (and incident triaging).
* Over the fence handovers. Fake promises by recruiters, lack of leadership.
* Walls between orgs for transfers and artificial, per-org devopment limitations. It's better to leave and reinterview with a chance of getting better offer than trying to move internally (and still going through the interviews) and getting your level frozen for a year.

There's some efforts to improve engineering practices, but get smudged and diluted by the lack of will and understanding from the leadership, and the lack of reward from the global org (doing two really crappy things gives you more performance review points than doing something with high quality, and/or refactoring any amount of the crappy things around).

- Most of the codebase I've seen is messy and badly documented. It is difficult to find what you need and understand what you find. Making an impact requires equal parts software engineering and archeology.
- There is *a lot* to learn w.r.t. internal pro
